verses.text: Now as John maintained a bold and ardent bearing, and his accusers seemed to grow faint-hearted, the bishops present, setting aside all other matters, said they would confine themselves to this sole consideration, that he had on his own responsibility, after his deposition, again seated himself in the episcopal chair, without being authorized by an ecclesiastical council.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 18:15
verses.text: As he alleged that sixty-five bishops who had held communion with him had reinstated him, the partisans of Leontius objected, saying: 'A larger number voted against you, John, in the Synod.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 18:16
verses.text: ' But although John then contended that this was a canon of the Arians, and not of the catholic church, and therefore it was inoperative against him—for it had been framed in the council convened against Athanasius at Antioch, for the subversion of the doctrine of consubstantiality  —the bishops would not listen to his defence, but immediately condemned him, without considering that by using this canon they were sanctioning the deposition of Athanasius himself.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 18:17
verses.text: This sentence was pronounced a little before Easter; the emperor therefore sent to tell John that he could not go to the church, because two Synods had condemned him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 18:18
verses.text: Accordingly Chrysostom was silenced, and went no more to the church; but those who were of his party celebrated Easter in the public baths which are called Constantianae, and thenceforth left the church.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 18:19
verses.text: Among them were many bishops and presbyters, with others of the clerical order, who from that time held their assemblies apart in various places, and were from him denominated 'Johannites.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 18:20
verses.text: ' For the space of two months, John refrained from appearing in public; after which a decree of the emperor sent him into exile.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 18:21
verses.text: Thus he was led into exile by force, and on the very day of his departure, some of the Johannites set fire to the church, which by means of a strong easterly wind, communicated with the senate-house.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 18:22
verses.text: This conflagration happened on the 20th of June, under the sixth consulate of Honorius, which he bore in conjunction with Aristaenetus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 18:23
verses.text: The severities which Optatus, the prefect of Constantinople, a pagan in religion, and a hater of the Christians, inflicted on John's friends, and how he put many of them to death on account of this act of incendiarism, I ought, I believe, to pass by in silence.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 19:2
verses.text: —Ordination of Arsacius as John's Successor.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 19:3
verses.text: Indisposition of Cyrinus Bishop of Chalcedon.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 19:4
verses.text: After the lapse of a few days, Arsacius was ordained bishop of Constantinople; he was a brother of Nectarius who so ably administered the see before John, although he was then very aged, being upwards of eighty years old.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 19:5
verses.text: While he very mildly and peacefully administered the episcopate, Cyrinus bishop of Chalcedon, upon whose foot Maruthas bishop of Mesopotamia had inadvertently trodden, became so seriously affected by the accident, that mortification ensued, and it became necessary to amputate his foot.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 19:6
verses.text: Nor was this amputation performed once only, but was required to be often repeated: for after the injured limb was cut off, the evil so permeated his whole system, that the other foot also having become affected by the disease had to submit to the same operation.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 19:7
verses.text: I have alluded to this circumstance, because many have affirmed that what he suffered was a judgment upon him for his calumnious aspersions of John, whom he so often designated as arrogant and inexorable,  as I have already said.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 19:8
verses.text: Furthermore as on the 30th of September, in the last-mentioned consulate,  there was an extraordinary fall of hail of immense size at Constantinople and its suburbs, it also was declared to be an expression of Divine indignation on account of Chrysostom's unjust deposition: and the death of the empress tended to give increased credibility to these reports, for it took place four days after the hail-storm.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 19:9
verses.text: Others, however, asserted that John had been deservedly deposed, because of the violence he had exercised in Asia and Lydia, in depriving the Novatians and Quartodecimans of many of their churches, when he went to Ephesus and ordained Heraclides.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 19:10
verses.text: But whether John's deposition was just, as his enemies declare, or Cyrinus suffered in chastisement for his slanderous revilings; whether the hail fell, or the empress died on John's account, or whether these things happened for other reasons, or for these in connection with others, God only knows, who is the discerner of secrets, and the just judge of truth itself.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 19:11
verses.text: I have simply recorded the reports which were current at that time.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 20:2
verses.text: —Death of Arsacius, and Ordination of Atticus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 20:3
verses.text: But Arsacius did not long survive his accession to the bishopric; for he died on the 11th of November under the following consulate, which was Stilicho's second, and the first of Anthemius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 20:4
verses.text: In consequence of the fact that the bishopric became desirable and many aspired to the vacant see, much time elapsed before the election of a successor: but at length in the following consulate, which was the sixth of Arcadius, and the first of Probus,  a devout man named Atticus was promoted to the episcopate.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 20:5
verses.text: He was a native of Sebastia in Armenia, and had followed an ascetic life from an early age: moreover in addition to a moderate share of learning, he possessed a large amount of natural prudence.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 20:6
verses.text: But I shall speak of him more particularly a little later.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 21:2
verses.text: —John dies in Exile.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 21:3
verses.text: John taken into exile died in Comana on the Euxine, on the 14th of September, in the following consulate, which was the seventh of Honorius, and the second of Theodosius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 21:4
verses.text: A man, as we have before observed,  who on account of zeal for temperance was inclined rather to anger than forbearance: and his personal sanctity of character led him to indulge in a latitude of speech which to others was intolerable.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 21:5
verses.text: Indeed, it is most inexplicable to me, how with a zeal so ardent for the practice of self-control and blamelessness of life, he should in his sermons appear to teach a loose view of temperance.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 21:6
verses.text: For whereas by the Synod of bishops repentance was accepted but once from those who had sinned after baptism; he did not scruple to say, 'Approach, although you may have repented a thousand times.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 21:7
verses.text: '  For this doctrine, many even of his friends censured him, but especially Sisinnius bishop of the Novatian; who wrote a book condemnatory of the above quoted expression of Chrysostom's, and severely rebuked him for it.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 21:8
verses.text: But this occurred long before.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:2
verses.text: —Of Sisinnius Bishop of the Novatians.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:3
verses.text: His Readiness at Repartee.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:4
verses.text: It will not be out of place here, I conceive, to give some account of Sisinnius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:5
verses.text: He was, as I have often said,  a remarkably eloquent man, and well-instructed in philosophy.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:6
verses.text: But he had particularly cultivated logic, and was profoundly skilled in the interpretation of the holy Scriptures; insomuch that the heretic Eunomius often shrank from the acumen which his reasoning displayed.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:7
verses.text: As regards his diet he was not simple; for although he practised the strictest moderation, yet his table was always sumptuously furnished.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:8
verses.text: He was also accustomed to indulge himself by wearing white garments, and bathing twice a day in the public baths.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:9
verses.text: And when some one asked him 'why he, a bishop, bathed himself twice a day?' he replied, 'Because it is inconvenient to bathe thrice.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:10
verses.text: ' Going one day from courtesy to visit the bishop Arsacius, he was asked by one of the friends of that bishop, 'why he wore a garment so unsuitable for a bishop? and where it was written that an ecclesiastic should be clothed in white?' 'Do you tell me first,' said he, 'where it is written that a bishop should wear black?' When he that made the inquiry knew not what to reply to this counter-question: 'You cannot show,' rejoined Sisinnius, 'that a priest should be clothed in black.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:11
verses.text: But Solomon is my authority, whose exhortation is, "Let thy garments be white".

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:12
verses.text: And our Saviour in the Gospels appears clothed in white raiment:  moreover he showed Moses and Elias to the apostles, clad in white garments.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:13
verses.text: ' His prompt reply to these and other questions called forth the admiration of those present.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:14
verses.text: Again when Leontius bishop of Ancyra in Galatia Minor, who had taken away a church from the Novatians, was on a visit to Constantinople, Sisinnius went to him, and begged him to restore the church.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:15
verses.text: But he received him rudely, saying, 'Ye Novatians ought not to have churches; for ye take away repentance, and shut out Divine mercy.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:16
verses.text: ' As Leontius gave utterance to these and many other such revilings against the Novatians, Sisinnius replied: 'No one repents more heartily than I do.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:17
verses.text: ' And when Leontius asked him 'Why do you repent?' 'That I came to see you,' said he.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:18
verses.text: On one occasion John the bishop having a contest with him, said, 'The city cannot have two bishops.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:19
verses.text: '  'Nor has it,' said Sisinnius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:20
verses.text: John being irritated at this response, said, 'You see you pretend that you alone are the bishop.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:21
verses.text: ' 'I do not say that,' rejoined Sisinnius; 'but that I am not bishop in your estimation only, who am such to others.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:22
verses.text: ' John being still more chafed at this reply, said, 'I will stop your preaching; for you are a heretic.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:23
verses.text: ' To which Sisinnius good-humoredly replied, 'I will give you a reward, if you will relieve me from so arduous a duty.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:24
verses.text: ' John being softened a little by this answer, said, 'I will not make you cease to preach, if you find speaking so troublesome.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:25
verses.text: ' So facetious was Sisinnius, and so ready at repartee: but it would be tedious to dwell further on his witticisms.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:26
verses.text: Wherefore by means of a few specimens we have illustrated what sort of a person he was, deeming these as sufficient.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:27
verses.text: I will merely add that he was celebrated for erudition, and on account of it all the bishops who succeeded him loved and honored him; and not only they but all the leading members of the senate also esteemed and admired him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:28
verses.text: He is the author of many works: but they are characterized by too great an affectation of elegance of diction, and a lavish intermingling of poetic expressions.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:29
verses.text: On which account he was more admired as a speaker than as a writer; for there was dignity in his countenance and voice, as well as in his form and aspect, and every movement of his person was graceful.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:30
verses.text: On account of these features he was loved by all the sects, and he was in especial favor with Atticus the bishop.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 22:31
verses.text: But I must conclude this brief notice of Sisinnius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 23:2
verses.text: —Death of the Emperor Arcadius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 23:3
verses.text: Not long after the death of John, the Emperor Arcadius died also.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 23:4
verses.text: This prince was of a mild and gentle disposition, and toward the close of his life was esteemed to be greatly beloved of God, from the following circumstance.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 23:5
verses.text: There was at Constantinople an immense mansion called Carya; for in the court of it there is a walnut tree on which it is said Acacius suffered martyrdom by hanging; on which account a chapel was built near it, which the Emperor Arcadius one day thought fit to visit, and after having prayed there, left again.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 23:6
verses.text: All who lived near this chapel ran in a crowd to see the emperor; and some going out of the mansion referred to, endeavored to preoccupy the streets in order to get a better view of their sovereign and his suite, while others followed in his train, until all who inhabited it, including the women and children, had wholly gone out of it.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 23:7
verses.text: No sooner was this vast pile emptied of its occupants, the buildings of which completely environed the church, than the entire building fell.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 23:8
verses.text: On which there was a great outcry, followed by shouts of admiration, because it was believed the emperor's prayer had rescued so great a number of persons from destruction.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 23:9
verses.text: This event occurred in that manner.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 23:10
verses.text: On the 1st of May, Arcadius died, leaving his son Theodosius only eight years old, under the consulate of Bassus and Philip, in the second year of the 297th Olympiad.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 23:11
verses.text: He had reigned thirteen years with Theodosius his father, and fourteen years after his death, and had then attained the thirty-first year of his age.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VI 23:12
verses.text: This book includes the space of twelve years and six months.
